Experience Staff Scientist - Computational Biology Stanford Center for Genomics and Personalized Medicine May 2013  – Present (2 years 4 months) Palo Alto, California I am affiliated with Stanford Center for Genomics and Personalized Medicine (SCGPM) at the Stanford School of Medicine where my main theme of research is in the area of bioinformatics for translational precision medicine.  
 
As the principal bioinformatician for Stanford Clinical Genomics Service (SCGS) I have designed and implemented the SCGS's clinically optimized genome processing and variation discovery pipeline (MedGAP) where I am also collaborating with a team of software engineers to enable cloud-based clinical genome processing for Stanford Hospital and SCGS. I am also member of the team for quality-control and post-processing and curation of genomic variations. 
 
In collaboration with Google Genomics and as part of Million Veteran Program (MVP) I am also leading projects to design cloud-based software systems to enable distributed genome processing and large-scale structural variation interpretation using statistical and machine learning methods.  
 
We have a rich research community at Stanford Dept. of Genetics. This has led me to collaborations with a number of other exciting projects on different topics such as statistical approaches to cancer evolution, cancer specific genomic assay design, family-based genomics, viral genomics, and epigenetics.  
 
I am also leading a number of SCGPM's activities to promote industry collaboration. This includes our current collaboration with Spiral Genomics Inc., Genalice Inc., Real Time Genomics Inc. as well as our past work with Seven Bridges Genomics and DNANexus.  
 
I am a mentor in recently established GeneCamp Outreach program at SCGPM where we work with summer high-school interns on real-life projects in personalized medicine.  Postdoctoral Research Fellow Ontario Institute for Cancer Research 2011  –  2013  (2 years) Toronto, Canada Area Worked on the application of next generation sequencing and SNP-array genotyping technologies in cancer biomarker detection. 
 
My research focused on evaluation and design of algorithms and methods for discovery and evaluation of genomic variations including copy number and structural variations.  
 
Part of results of these studies were used in an Internationally funded project, Canadian Prostate Cancer Genome, as part of International Cancer Genome Consortium (ICGC), to discover underlying genomic signature of medium risk prostate cancer and to verify prostate tumor heterogeneity for diagnostic and prognostic purposes. Postdoctoral Research Fellow University of Toronto 2009  –  2011  (2 years) Toronto, Ontario, Canada Worked on statistical approach to molecular evolution and evolutionary sequencing analysis in general. Also worked on the application of information theory in characterization of protein binding sites, statistical prediction of the effect of large scale genomic variations on protein function. PhD Student McMaster University 2001  –  2006  (5 years) Hamilton, Ontario, Canada Statistical signal processing, Bayesian tracking, filtering and prediction, interplay of statistics and information theory, distributed estimation and compression. Summary Current research: Method development and application of SRM/AQUA/TMT/SILAC to peptide quantification  
 
Expertise and Research Experience 
 
•	Expertise on Protein Mass Spectrometry	 
−	Liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry 
−	Digestion of protein in gel, on beads, in solution and on column  
−	Construction of microcapillary nanoflow HPLC columns 
−	Operation and maintenance of mass spectrometers (LTQ, LTQ-Orbitrap, LTQ-FT-ICR ) 
−	Manual annotation of ETD/CAD/HCD spectra 
−	Mass spectrometry software: XCalibur, OMSSA, Proteome Discoverer, Mascot, ProSightPC 
 
•	Graduate Research Summary 
−	Protein PTMs characterization using ETD and CAD 
−	Application of immobilized metal affinity chromatography (IMAC) and metal oxide affinity chromatography (MOAC) to enrich phosphopeptides 
−	Middle-down sequencing of monoclonal antibodies using immobilized protease for size-controlled proteolysis 
−	Employment of search algorithms and bioinformatics tools to facilitate mass spectral data analysis 
 
•	Industrial Experience on Monoclonal Antibody Characterization 
−	Intact mass analysis 
−	Reduced peptide mapping 
−	Disulfide bond linkage characterization 
−	N-glycan analysis 
−	Monoclonal antibody de novo sequencing 
−	IND and BLA regulatory filings Summary Current research: Method development and application of SRM/AQUA/TMT/SILAC to peptide quantification

Summary I have found that effective communication, critical analysis, and collaboration are key for success in science. I am a team-oriented scientist who leads from the bench and has a passion for performing hypothesis-driven research. Experience Member of the Board of Directors Santa Clara Valley Science & Engineering Fair Association (SCVSEFA) July 2015  – Present (2 months) Silicon Valley The mission of SCVSEFA is: to awaken more students to the wonder and power of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). This is accomplished by holding an annual, regional Science and Engineering Fair for 6th-12th grade students (usually 900 - 1000 participants). Staff Scientist Stanford University November 2014  – Present (10 months) San Francisco Bay Area Postdoctoral Researcher Stanford University September 2012  –  November 2014  (2 years 3 months) The proper folding of many newly-synthesized proteins requires the assistance of molecular chaperones because the crowded intracellular environment can promote protein misfolding and aggregation. TRiC is a molecular chaperone required for the proper production of tumor suppressor proteins as well as critical components of the cytoskeleton. I developed molecular sensors to monitor TRiC function in cells. These sensors can be employed to assay TRiC function in diverse conditions such as stress and models of human pathological states. Math & Science Tutor San Francisco State University September 2003  –  June 2004  (10 months) Learning Assistance Center I worked with the diverse population of SFSU including students of different backgrounds, religions, and ages. Prior to starting, I received over ten hours of workshops that taught me effective approaches to assist students develop effective problem solving strategies.

 Curriculum Designer UC Santa Barbara June 2002  –  June 2003  (1 year 1 month) Santa Barbara, California Area Created web-based learning modules to explore structure/function relationships of biological macromolecules (Computational Biochemistry Laboratory course) Curriculum Designer UC Santa Barbara June 2002  –  June 2003  (1 year 1 month) Santa Barbara, California Area Created web-based learning modules to explore structure/function relationships of biological macromolecules (Computational Biochemistry Laboratory course) Languages   Skills Molecular Biology Cell Biology Cell Culture Biochemistry Western Blotting Microscopy PCR Science Fluorescence Microscopy Molecular Cloning Genetics Protein Purification Protein Expression Immunohistochemistry Cell Life Sciences Research See 2+     See less Skills  Molecular Biology Cell Biology Cell Culture Biochemistry Western Blotting Microscopy PCR Science Fluorescence Microscopy Molecular Cloning Genetics Protein Purification Protein Expression Immunohistochemistry Cell Life Sciences Research See 2+     See less Molecular Biology Cell Biology Cell Culture Biochemistry Western Blotting Microscopy PCR Science Fluorescence Microscopy Molecular Cloning Genetics Protein Purification Protein Expression Immunohistochemistry Cell Life Sciences Research See 2+     See less Molecular Biology Cell Biology Cell Culture Biochemistry Western Blotting Microscopy PCR Science Fluorescence Microscopy Molecular Cloning Genetics Protein Purification Protein Expression Immunohistochemistry Cell Life Sciences Research See 2+     See less Education Stanford University Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.),  Cell/Cellular and Molecular Biology 2006  – 2012 During my doctoral training in the Gozani lab I: 
1) Studied human protein modules that sense lysine methylation events which play a principal role in governing epigenetic processes. I, in collaboration with other members of the lab, screened through a library of putative methyl-lysine binding domains, which resulted in the identification of several new modification-dependent chromatin binders. 
 
2) Discovered a critical role for the phospholipid phosphatidylinositol-5-phosphate (PI5P) in the stress-induced gene expression program mediated by ING2, a member of the human Inhibitor of Growth family of tumor suppressors. I took a genomic approach to globally identify promoters bound by ING2 in the presence of DNA damage as well as the subsequent gene expression changes. My investigation uncovered that a node of the ING2 network is dysregulated when ING2 cannot associate with PtdIns(5)P. This work establishes a novel role for PtdIns(5)P as a cofactor that targets ING2 to gene promoters. San Francisco State University Master of Science (M.S.),  Microbiology , General 2004  – 2006 I was the recipient of the Minority Biomedical Research Support (MBRS) Research Initiative for Scientific Enhancement (RISE) scholarship from the National Institutes of Health (NIH). Summary I am a student at the University of Colorado at Boulder, studying Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology. I am currently taking a one year absence from school while I conduct biomedical research in the Glenn lab at Stanford University. My research focuses on the discovery of novel Hepatitis C Virus and Dengue Virus therapies. Experience Research Associate Stanford University May 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year 4 months) Stanford, CA As a member of the Glenn lab at Stanford University I primarily research the molecular mechanisms of Hepatitis C Virus, Dengue Virus in an effort to discover novel molecular pathways that can be used as potential drug targets. My research also includes Influenza, Tuberculosis, and other viruses.
